annotation.TEXT: For beating Zero, you get the Z-Saber chip. The upcoming cutscene also plays out differently depending on whether or not you picked up the gold mystery data in the Old Area (but then again, why wouldn't you pick it up?). If you didn't get the data, Zero will be deleted. If you got the data however, Zero lives and you'll get something extra at the end of the incoming plot dump. In relation to that: Yes, the rest of this video is basically just all cutscenes. If you want to see what the reward is for saving Zero, skip to 13:49.

For getting the mystery data and saving Zero, we get his Navi chip. Both the chip and Z-Saber do basically the same thing (three sword swings, all with big damage output). While relatively strong, there's a catch in that they both only have one use in their ammo reserves. If you're ever going to use at least one of these, definitely go for his Navi Chip. Plus, getting his Navi Chip is required if you want to take on the secret boss of this game.

Transitioning ahead a small bit, it's time to take on the Zero Account. Though it's only made up of one area, this place can still be very dangerous, especially if you're not packing chips that deal 100 damage or more (this is mostly due to the abundance of Aura Heads found in the lower sections).

Gravity Man's chips are pretty decent for the most part. His ability chip is the Gravity Bomb, a slow moving projectile that deals multiple hits as it travels through enemies. His Navi chip is essentially a much better version of Bright Man's chip, since it effectively works as a screen-clearer that takes out most minor enemies. Naturally though, it does nothing to bosses (its damage value is 0, after all).

For as much as I like StarMan.EXE, his Navi chip is a let down. It emulates his star rain ability, but it's nowhere near as good as when he uses it. The stars themselves tend to fall in unreliable positions (some of which fall behind your current position), and they can sometimes get caught up on higher platforms and ceilings. Granted, if you somehow do get most of them to hit, it has the potential to deal absurd amounts of damage. Once again, however: Multi-hitting chips are useless for bosses.

I'd like to pose a serious question: What is Capcom's obsession with giving Zero unavoidable moves? Zero.EXE himself is virtually unremarkable aside from that one trait (you hit him, he counters by teleporting behind you and attacking, you hit him back, repeat). Once you get his health down low enough, he'll power up and use two gigantic sword slashes. As far as I can tell, there's no way to avoid taking damage from this attack unless you're using Invis, Barrier, or Stone/Steel/Metal Body chips. Also, before anyone says anything: No, you can't knock him out of this (he's invincible while charging up).

By comparison however, his ability chip is pretty neat. The Star Arrow is basically the Super Arrow from MM5, only it doesn't stick into walls. The only downside is that it comes way too late in the game to be of any real use. A good portion of the last few levels are more vertical than horizontal, meaning you'll get very few opportunities to use this effectively.

As mentioned before, this is where the Aura Heads start becoming a problem. While you can try to lure them into attacking and hit their exposed heads, they move way too fast for this to be viable option. Get some M-Cannons, Tree Bombs, or a variety of elemental chips before coming here.

Another video, another re-match before the main event. This time however, we're doing two in a row: Gravity Man and Star Man. Just to note, I did some off-screen grinding in the Abnormal Gravity stage (as painful as it was). It took some time, but I eventually got enough new chips to make some decent improvements to my folder - the end results of which you're about to see.

Also, getting lost is never fun. I don't know why, but I've always had trouble getting around in the lower area of this place. It's not that complex of a stage, but it's certainly easy to miss everything it has to offer when it comes to mystery data.

The Popper viruses found here are capable of dropping the DropDown chip. As a word of advice: Don't bother with it. DropDown is essentially a far worse version of Invis and Metal Body. Using it makes you invicible...until you attack with anything, at which point your invulnerability immediately wears off. That's also not to mention that there's a far better invincibility granting chip you can find in the next stage (if you have the patience to obtain it, that is).
